dt: {bc}a person to whom hospitality is extended
{bc}a person who pays for the services of an establishment (such as a hotel or restaurant)
{bc}an organism (such as an insect) sharing the dwelling of another
{bc}a substance that is incorporated in a host substance
{bc}a usually prominent person not a regular member of a cast or organization who appears in a program or performance

et: Middle English {it}gest, gyst, gust, gist{/it} "person to whom hospitality is extended, visitor, stranger," going back to Old English {it}giest, gyst, gest, gæst{/it} (with Middle English {it}g{/it} probably in part from Old Norse {it}gestr{/it}), going back to Germanic {it}*gasti-{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}jest{/it} "guest," Old Saxon & Old High German {it}gast{/it} "guest, stranger," Old Norse {it}gestr,{/it} Gothic {it}gasts{/it} "stranger") going back to dialectal Indo-European {it}*ghost-i-{/it} "outsider, guest," whence also Old Church Slavic {it}gostĭ{/it} "guest," Latin {it}hostis{/it} "foreigner, stranger" (in early use), "enemy"

An etymon limited to three western Indo-European branches. Further analysis of the word has been made on the basis of early use of Latin {it}hostis,{/it} taken to mean, on the basis of the Law of the Twelve Tables, "outsider due the same right of ownership as a Roman citizen"; from the same base would be {it}hostus{/it} "yield of olive oil from a single pressing" (narrowed from a presumed more general "yield, compensation"), the derived verb {it}hostīre{/it} "to recompense, requite," and the noun {it}hostia{/it} "sacrificial animal, sacrifice" ("recompense to the gods," perhaps originally feminine of an adjective {it}*hostius,{/it} the deleted noun having designated an animal; see {et_link|host:5|host:5}). Ancestral {it}*ghos-ti-{/it} could hypothetically be a derivative of an Indo-European verbal base {it}*ǵhes-{/it} "take, give in exchange." With the loss in later Roman practice of the strict legal meaning, Latin {it}hostis{/it} became restricted in meaning to "hostile outsider, enemy." This shift is noted by {et_link|varro|Varro:b}, who remarked that {it}hostis{/it} was used by "our ancestors" in a sense now covered by {it}peregrīnus{/it} (see {et_link|pilgrim|pilgrim}).
shortdef: a person entertained in one's house
a person to whom hospitality is extended
a person who pays for the services of an establishment (such as a hotel or restaurant)
